Our emotions are a gift from God.
But in order to recieve the blessing we must first realize that our emotions are always connected to a need being met or unmet.
By listening to our emotions and asking ourselves why we are feeling a particular emotion we can discover an unmet need or a need that has been satisfied.
Probably too many to count.
So, what can we do?
Well, for starters become aware of what we are feeling.
We can become conscious of what is going on inside us.
Once we put our finger on the emotion we are feeling we can then go on to vocalize it.
Marshall Rosenberg, author of Nonviolent Communication, has a four-step process for communication that incorporates identifying our feelings and needs into the model.
Part of that model involves asking the question, "I am feeling _______ because I am needing ______."
Rosenberg also calls this four step process "giraffe language."
He coined it giraffe language because the giraffe has the largest heart of all the mammals.
The heart is about 3 feet long and 3 inches thick all around.
The idea is that Nonviolent communication, which focuses on feelings and needs is the language of the heart because it focuses on what is alive in the heart.
We can then go on to making a request instead of a demand to help ourselves satisfy our now recognized need.
We can ask them, "Are you feeling ______ because you are needing _______?"
If we are not correct they will correct us and we will be closer to identifying the need they have and finding a way to resolve the situation.
By satisfying our needs and the needs of others we can reach a fair negotiation.
We can make a list of these feelings and be on the look out for them.
It may be that we need to take a timeout when we feel these feelings to avoid a conflict.
Then when we are calm, focus on sharing our feelings and needs with others.
For more information on Nonviolent Communication click here.

Hijab is a headscarf that covers the hair and usually wraps around the neck.

This is called the nikab.
For clarification the difference should be noted.
Hijab in Islam actually means modesty or privacy.
And it is believed that women should practice modesty both for themselves but to keep the gazing eyes of man down.
The khimar is the actual headscarf.
The veil that covers the entire face is called the nikab.
Islam requires women to be modest, henceforth many of them wear the hijab, or headscarf.
The nikab, or taliban style cover, is not an Islamic practice.

What I completed in one day today, was not possible to me last week.
Today, I can say I actually taught for all three of my periods.
I walked into my first period only to find a sub.
I decided then and there that I would take advantage of the situation and teach the class.
I asked the sub if he did not mind my taking over, and of course he complied.
I figured I knew the material more than he did, and more importantly I knew the students and how the class should run.
So the bell rang, the sub introduced himself and I took over.
I had them write in their journals for a few minutes, then proceeded to facilitate the day's assignments.
I allowed them 10-15 minutes to finish up the work from yesterday before we began a new piece of literature.
After they turned that in, I introduced "Poor Richard's Almanac," which we read as a class.
This was a very short reading so I gave the class an assignment to go along with the reading.
They had the remainder of the class to complete the assignment while I went around to monitor their work and answer questions.
On the other hand, I did know that today I was to teach a full period lesson to my freshmen for periods 3 & 6.
I began my lesson by explaining what the term "mood" meant.
I explained to them that the "mood" of the story could be determined based on the word choice used by the author.
To give them a better understanding of how "mood" works, I presented them with a paragraph that I wrote on the overhead.
I had them follow along as I read out loud.
After I was done reading my paragraph, I had the students tell me what was the mood I had created.
That was a segway into today's story.
Today we read, "The Talk" by Gary Soto.
I gave a brief background on the author and the story before we began.
I read the first paragraph, then I drew names out of my little tin container to complete the reading.
After certain spots, I would have them go over plot summary just to make sure they were following along.
At the end of the story, I had them do the same thing they did with my paragraph to determine the mood.
After a discussion, I asked them to take out a piece of paper.
They answered on their papers, then shared out as a class.
This completed my very first lesson for periods 3 & 6.

You know you're from Massachusetts when.
When ordering a tonic, you mean a Coke.
You know how to pronounce the names of towns like Worcester, Billerica, Haverhill, Barre and Cotuit.
You have driven to New Hampshire on a Sunday in order to get beer.
You know what they sell at a packie.
You know at least one bar where you can get something to drink after last call.
You can actually find your way around Boston.
Evacuation Day is a recognized holiday.
You know at least one guy named Sean, Pat, Whitey, Red, Bud or Seamus.
You think the rest of the country owes you for Thanksgiving and Independence Day.
You have never been to Cheers.
You have gone to at least one party at UMass.
You think Doug Flutie is the greatest athlete ever.
You remember exactly where you were when the ball rolled through Buckner's legs.
You pray for the Red Sox to win the World Series not this season, but in your lifetime.
You know how to make a frappe.
You know that "Big Dig" is also a kind of ice cream you can get at Brigham's.
You actually know how to merge from 6 lanes of traffic down to one.
You never go to "Cape Cod", you go "down the Cape".
You went to Old Sturbridge Village, Plymouth Plantation, or both, on field trip in grammar school.
You're aware that there is a town, somewhere in Massachusetts, named Brimfield where they have the biggest outdoor antique market in the world.
You can drive to the mountains and the ocean all in one day.
You know that the Mass Pike is some sort of strange weather dividing line.
You know that P-Town isn't the name of a new rap group.
You do not recognize the letter "R" as a part of the English language.
You keep an ice scraper and can of de-icer on the floor of your car.

I've been thinking a great deal about the importance of ritual.
Not religious ritual (like baptism) or societal ritual (like shaking hands), but personal ritual.
I've been wondering which aspects of a behavior determine whether it's ritual or rut.
And how I can possibly develop more rituals and fewer ruts in my life.
This has all come about because lately, I've been thinking about the Big Picture.
Granted, not the global, world-issues Big Picture, just MY Big Picture.
The same thought keeps coming back to me: I lived my first 40 years largely as a leaf, blowing about in the wind.
Like that bag in American Beauty.
it was not self-determined.
I want the next 40 years to be lived on purpose.
How do I do that?
And how can I start now?
And, the corollary: how easy it is to slip into old habits, once back at home.
[It makes sense that there is concern for addicts or alcoholics who successfully gets straight or sober some place other than where they live.
and then eventually have to return home to old triggers.]
That, and they may not be exactly great for you.
I'm not advocating all-structure, all-the-time or anything.
At least in my experience.
I'd like to say that my rituals are more active and crunchy.
Here are some rituals I HAVE managed to cultivate:
* Every day when I come home from work, the first thing I do is put on my pajamas.
Maybe that doesn't sound like a ritual.
* Every other Saturday, Catharine and I get manicures and pedicures.
A time to relax, be pampered, catch up.
and we come away with the cutest toes ever!
Maybe after this show ends, I'll be able to start a new garden.
I've just realized in trying to make a list of my rituals, that I really don't have many.
and the like are what come to mind.
Is that a rut.
or just something totally mental that I do?
Anyway, I don't want to sully this post with MY list of rituals and ruts.
How do you think we can instill more meaningful rituals into our lives?
From talking with cartoonists, I get the sense that most of them find it debilitating, too.
That means I didn't see the Ignatz Awards, didn't partake of any post-show gatherings, and missed a big chunk of panels.
My SPX, in other words, was full of shopping and stalking the aisles.
There were no signs to direct you to the panels or whatnot, though it wasn't hard to find someone to ask direction of.
Downstairs there were hushed people crouched before open doors, the portals leading to capacity talks.
All of it in a building off the highway, malls and fences and the whipping metal sea of vehicles all around it.
It was a hotel, on a road.
But we didn't hang around.
A diverse audience too, everything from young to old, from old-school nerds to stylish-looking folk, from aged hippies to teenage Goths.
To look only at this crowd, you'd imagine that there was no question as to the diversity of the comics-reading audience.
I went to two panels, Scott McCloud's and Brian Chippendale's.
There was nowhere to sit in the former, since I got there late, so I sort of drifted in and out of hearing distance.
Someone behind me turned to someone else and whispered "It's just like Civil War."
Nobody was particularly brusque at SPX, at least from among the artists, but I found Chippendale to be consistently the most emphatic and friendly creator around.
And I bought a good deal of stuff too.
I tried to follow Tom's rule of not buying anything on my first trip around the room, but that didn't quite hold.

My Mother Is A Fish
Do you know some tiger sharks sleep?
I don't sleep.
No, it's alright, I've had a lot of time to come to terms with this.
Most of the time, I sit in a chair.
To try and remedy this, I spend my nights reading.
I just finished a book about the importance of dreams.
How important can they be?
I don't have them and I'm still here.
Sometimes, I can't reading about this condition, though.
I guess it's hard to read about a condition when you don't know the name of it.
I didn't always have this problem.
When I was a kid I slept.
Actually, I don't remember much about my childhood.
All this not sleeping has a terrible way of playing with your memory.
I don't only feel like the days stretch on interminably.
They really do when there's no end.
Just me in my room, reading my books and wondering what life would be like if I slept.
Do I go to work again tomorrow morning?
I think I do.
It's Sunday, but tomorrow might be a holiday.
It is, isn't it?
But I think I work on that holiday.
I actually keep one everywhere, one in my car, one in each room of my apartment, one in my cubicle.
How else would I keep all these days straight?
It's not like a sleep in on the weekend.
I can't always read about this condition, or whatever it may be.
I'm beginning to think there may be nothing to it.
I'd tell my doctor, but I don't go to a doctor.
Otherwise, I'm a totally healthy male of my species.
Something from when I was a kid.
And there's the scar on my lip.
I don't know where that came from.
I would say it was from some drunken night of excess, but I've never blacked out either.
I can drink and drink.
Oh, I get drunk, but nothing seems to happen to me where I forget.
Selective memory, they say.
Most times, I can't even remember what I did five seconds ago.
You'd think that'd be a problem at work, but it's menial stuff.
Doesn't require much of a brain to do it.
Have you ever read it?
It's kind of confusing.
I kept having to reread passages until I figured out that it's not chronological.
I think he had a point.
But I can't remember it right now.
I'm at work, and I left the book at home.
I'll have to look when I get home.
Unless I returned it to the library.
I walk to work.
When it's nice.
It's a couple miles, but I don't have a lot of people that I have to rush home to see.
Just my books these days.
I really need to get more friends.
My walk takes me by Lake Calhoun.
Most days I look at it as I pass by the fishers, the runners, the dog walkers.
Every so often, I walk around it.
I don't know what it is about the lake.
A shelf of clouds cover the sky, and Calhoun, choppy from the breeze, glitters only slightly.
I itch my neck for some reason it itches.
Soon the lake will be frozen, everyone walking on top of it.
I don't get it.
Just like the fisherman.
Doesn't seem fair, not at all.
I amble around the lake, and the people are slowly thinning out.
I guess it's getting colder, and it's getting to be time for dinner, or far enough after work, or whatever.
I should have brought a book with me. Then I could read at the lake
People tell me that the water in the lakes around here isn't that good.
But people swim in this, right?
And there are plenty of fish.
The water can't be that bad.
And it's not that cold yet.
I control it at first.
A person walks by me and says something, but I don't know what, and I'm singing something, but I can't place to tune.
Something my mother sang to me to put me to sleep.
I could be wrong.
But where else would I know it from.
I don't listen to music, but I know this song.
I just throw my clothes in a pile.
I can see people running at me as I dive into Calhoun.
My neck tingles as I hit the water and I sink, blowing bubbles.
They slowly stop coming out of my mouth, but my neck continues to tingle.
For the first time in my life I feel completely normal.
I read somewhere that fish don't sleep.
Except for some tiger sharks.
You're going to hear that a lot from me in the coming weeks, I think.
But it's all good when folks need or want something, isn't it?
But for now, I go hide.
It's nice kind of being able to put everything together in my head.

I stand barefoot by the ocean's edge, my feet sinking slowly, being sucked beneath the surface of the cool, wet sand.
I am planted there.
watching Mother Nature's lightshow, I see
enormous mounds of gray cotton batting clouds, only momentarily visible as they are back-lit by silent, random flashbulbs.
The sand wrapping my feet is now warmer than the air.
I stretch my arms out as far as they will reach just as the first drum rolls of thunder pound my ears.
Slightly swaying with the breeze, I can feel the deep vibration moving through me. around me. and away.
Being the tallest object on the beach in a thunderstorm and living to write about it.

Try out this first primer, a quick five minute guide to learning and loving classical music.
If these prissy little installments are truly helpful, I may just have to take more requests!
Welcome to the world of classical music.
It's the oldest recognized type of music in Western civilization, and it dates back well into the Middle Ages.
Since classical music is the oldest and largest genre of music in existence, let's study this music from one era to the next.
Most music historians identify anywhere from four to seven distinct eras in classical music, and since I recognize all seven, let's learn about each one:
Middle Ages (450 A.D. to 1450 A.D): Shortly after the fall of the Roman Empire, the first era of classical music was born.
There was no formal system of notation, making composing very difficult and time-consuming.
Gregorian chants were written during these ancient times.
Music became more of an expressive art than a science, and music was now being printed, allowing sacred, secular, and instrumental music to spread everywhere.
Governments now influenced the spread of the era's music more than the church.
Claudio Montiverdi was one of the most prominent composers of this era.
Composers developed the idea of the sonata, the concerto, and the symphony, where great performers (called virtuosos) found enormous success.
Composers used counterpoint, dance rhythms and repetition in their music.
Think of this brief period as a launch platform of all the modern music to follow.
Anyway, classical music wasn't even called classical music back in this time.
They used simple ideas, simple textures, and simple forms, all of which make for great listening material.
Composers of this era such as Tchaikovsky, Brahms, and Chopin wrote music with a wider dynamic range, using a larger variety of instruments.
Female composers gained more visibility during this period, such as Clara Schumann.
20th Century: 1900-1999: Classical music exploded, evolved and splintered faster than it ever had before.
New subcategories of classical music were born every year, and more composers were writing music than all previous eras combined.
Music of this era was influenced by anything and everything, including world wars, politics, SEX, and cross-pollination by other types of music such as jazz.
And anything and everything was possible, from atonal to experimental to electronic.
Finally, music could be recorded and distributed widely, creating a burgeoning market for all types of new music.
Over one hundred thousand composers fall into this period, including Copland, Stravinsky, and Ravel.
Needless to say, neither the church nor the government contributed much to classical music in this century.
Contemporary Classical: 1970 - 2050 (projected): If the 20th Century period ends in 1999, then what do we call all classical music written thereafter?
That was painless, wasn't it?
There is so much more to learn, but this is your first step into removing the mystery from these vast eras.
Your next few leaps into classical music should now be a little easier!

Measure 40 amends the state constitution to require supreme court and appeals judges to be elected by district instead of the statewide vote that currently happens.
Arguments in favor: 29
Arguments in opposition: 20
8 of the "pro" arguments consist of someone listing what I take to be every single county in Oregon from which there are no appellate judges.
Both sides have a mixture of more polemic arguments and more reasonable arguments.
All in all, most of the arguments are not very convincing one way or the other.
One of the few that seemed to me to say something worth saying was an argument in favor that was written by Ron Saxton.
The one other somewhat-convincing argument was immediately after that one, also in favor, by an organization of Oregon farmers.
They talked about how it would be nice if some of the appellate judges understood how farms operate when lawsuits against farmers come up.
There seemed to be at least a smidgen of personal experience reflected in that argument, something not really present anywhere else.
So I'm leaning slightly in favor, although I mostly don't see how it will make that big of a difference.

In the 3rd inning, I tried to score when a throw to third base got away.
I came racing down the line as Ryan Shalek picked up the loose ball and fired a strike to home plate.
Joey, who was blocking home plate, reached up and snared the ball as I arrived at the plate.
I tucked my shoulder down and leveled a defenseless Joe.
He went flying backwards and landed with a huge thud in the left-handed batter's box.
When I asked him whether he was all right, he said he was and proceeded to tell me that he knew it was coming.
He saw the play unfolding but had no way to brace for it because of the high throw and the simultaneous arrival of me and the ball.
Oh well, how often does one see a collision at home plate anyway?
You just have to think though of the consequences when two people meet at one point in that vicious a nature.
Who can forget Ray Fosse and Pete Rose's encounter at home plate in the 12th inning of the 1970 All Star Game?
This play remains perdurably etched in baseball history as the greatest play at the plate of all time.
Pete Rose scores the game-winning run and Ray Fosse, the Indians' seemingly promising beacon, is never the same ball player.
So, in the end, we held on to win by a score of 18-13.
Joe was fine after taking one of the hardest shots any catcher has ever taken in the six years we've been playing ball together.

There is nothing like being in a train wreck at home plate especially if you hang on to the ball for the out.
Joe said it doesn't happen that often so it doesn't bother him.
It would if it were a constant occurence but that was the first time this year that we had had a collision at home plate and probably the last.

I remember it as though it were yesterday.
June 5th, 2003.
Joe was on third and there was a runner on second with one out in a 6-6 tie in the bottom of the 6th inning.
We were intentionally walking Ahsan to load the bases up.
As I threw one of the pitches back to Billy, Joe broke for home plate.
I screamed for Billy to throw it and he did.
I jumped in front of home plate and the ball deflected off my glove and Joe just crushed me. He bounced off me and rolled behind home plate.
I landed by the ball and picked it up with my bare hand.
Ahsan says he still remembers that play.
Ahsan told me that he remembers the collision mostly because the game was being played in the rain and we very rarely play when it's raining.
He saw us sprawled out on the ground and thought for sure Joe was out.
Then he saw the ball lying on the ground and screamed for Joe to touch home.
It was as if they had won the World Series.
They completely mobbed Joe and were bounding around home plate as if Joe were the king of baseball.
All right, that's all I want to say.

And not even that I can't relate, or try to.
And I don't mean "don't fit in" in a sort of sad-emo-subculture-wearing black all the time thing.
I just don't.
What also started me thinking like this is the whole dating issue.
There are not a lot of guys that I will go for.
There is a type and he's very elusive.
But, back to reasons that I don't relate to *74%* of humanity:
- I don't think that the place to meet a potential love interest is at a party.
(And you know what kind I mean, because parties in general are okay, but I mean drunken ragers and the like.)
- I don't think it's okay to display women provocatively everywhere just to sell a product.

- I don't drink excessive amounts to project an image of being cool.
I don't drink excessive amounts because I am bored.
- I don't like the movie "Top Gun."
- I try not to listen to rap because it perpetuates stereotypes.
- I don't say "like" every other word.
Nor do I continually inflect the ends of my sentences upwards.
I could go on.
I get the feeling that a lot of people want to be like that.
Its not my bag and I don't really even want to be around it.
